blog/bart-homeomorphism.title: Homeomorphisms, Invariants, and BART; oh my!
blog/bart-homeomorphism.content:
intro! and what this post aims to do
This is a hand hold-y article. This is meant to build intuition around a topic that can be very very complex and can often leave you battered, weak, and frail. I aim not to do that! In fact, basically the whole article is:
(Though there ended up being much cool stuff here, so may be worth it for you to come back to later.)
Instead, I hope to give a single, small kernel of truth that is actually used in higher level mathematics, but also simple enough that youâ€™ve already used it in your life and will become one of those things you canâ€™t unsee (as those are the easiest ideas to build on top of ğŸ‘¼)
Iâ€™d like to do this by:

showing how this neat mathe-magical tool is already working and helping you in your own life
how this same tool is used by higher level mathematicians to solve hairy problems
ideally while keeping it NON-ANXIETY INDUCING and actually pretty simple (along with some historical context and â€˜smell the flowersâ€™ tidbits)

~ Off we go!! ~
MATH and BART
San Fransisco is pretty cool. We have public transit (and maps of it)


BART Map #1 (source: curtiswrightmaps.com/wp-content/uploads/map_32.35x24.22_02-27-24_inv005986-scaled.jpg)



Map #2 (source: www.reddit.com/media%3A%2F%2Fpreview.redd.it%2Fe13guqvbrl3c1.jpg%3Fwidth%3D3600%26format%3Dpjpg%26auto%3Dwebp%26s%3D95000fa1edb9c65063980e77eb0edda326478437)

I prefer this one though since itâ€™s a bit easier to read


Map #3 (source: s.hdnux.com/photos/01/12/00/20/19399708/3/rawImage.jpg)

And hereâ€™s an even further stripped down version of that same map: 

Map #4 (source: www.reddit.com/media%3A%2F%2Fi.redd.it%2Ftk1q3kigp4wc1.png)

Thereâ€™s presumably some advantage to having these stripped down maps, but letâ€™s compare a couple more just to see:
  

Map #5 (left) Map #6 (right)

For both of these, count the number of stops between Pittsburg/Bay Point and Lafayette. One is basically a number line, the other is a trail to traverse. (This may seem tedious, but weâ€™ll be using maps later for a similar reason.)
When you look at any of the squiggly areas of Map 6 (or any of the info heavy maps) it adds some cognitive tax to make sure you havenâ€™t missed a stop or gotten off track or whatever else; with the straight line you just count the dots and youâ€™re done.
You can further test this with the previous maps; try counting on map 1 how many stops it is to get from Colma (Red line) to West Dublin/Pleasanton (Blue), El Cerrito del Norte (Red) to Concord (Yellow), or OAK Airport (Grey, right hand side of the Bay) to Glen Park (Red). Actually try one of these examples! Itâ€™s your qualia at stake.
Then, try any of these on map 3 or 4 and at least I feel how much easier it is to locate these things. But why is that?
ğŸ¼ â€œWhatâ€™s the use?â€ ğŸµ
Thereâ€™s basically two things that are happening here:

we remove non-essential info
we retain essential info

Quiz time. While Iâ€™m riding the BART do I need to know:

Q: What mountain ranges (Map 1) are in the Bay to get to SFO? A: Hell no
Q: That North Concord is to the West of Pittsburg/Bay Point? A: HELL no

So we can get rid of that!
But what do you need to keep? You must keep the connections that BART actually makes in real life (like North Berkeley connects directly to Downtown Berkeley in each of the maps and SFO didnâ€™t magically connect to OAK airport somehow), otherwise the map is now out of touch with reality. KEEP THE CONNECTIVITY.
We can move them in whatever shape we want to, but as long as we donâ€™t 1. create / destroy stops, or 2. create / destroy connections then we can use it to accurately plan on the BART.
Thatâ€™s it!
Concept Exposition
there are math terms concepts hidden here, letâ€™s make them obvious so we can compare the actual math to our BART example. (donâ€™t worry too much about knowing EXACTLY what everything means, just make associations)
Homeomorphism (big boi)
When we take one map and change it to another (â€œsameâ€, but â€œdifferentâ€) map, thatâ€™s called a â€œhomeomorphismâ€. This can roughly be broken into:

homeo = â€œsameâ€
morphism = â€œshape, form, structureâ€

â€œSame structureâ€ == they have the same connections.
We could talk about homeomorphisms by saying â€œMap 1 and 2 are homeomorphic to each otherâ€ or â€œMap 2 is a homeomorphic transformation of Map 1â€. And we can say this for all four maps, theyâ€™re all homeomorphic to each other. Theyâ€™re all â€œthe sameâ€ in some way (same connections!), but theyâ€™re also all â€œdifferentâ€ from each other (different shapes and details and stuff).
Invariant:
â€œSame structureâ€, but some things are differentâ€¦but some things are the same? Yes! and those things that stay the same are the â€œinvariantsâ€ because theyâ€¦donâ€™t vary. MATHEMATICIAN YOU ARE!
Again, in the case of these maps, whatâ€™s not changing are the connections or the connectivity of said maps. In every map you can get from North Berkeley to Downtown Berkeley, Downtown Berkeley to Union City, Union City to Balboa Park. Since those connections are the same in every map, we can use every map to plan our travel. Invariant!!
Why are these useful to know about?
Practically, look at the maps above and see how some are easier to work with than others.
More specifically, we can change problems and remove information so that theyâ€™re easier to work with, while still having our representations be true. For example, Fermatâ€™s Last Theorem was unsolved for 350 years, put into a different form and then became possible to solve.

This one looks quite simple, but again it was unsolved for 350 years before someone made it â€œsimpleâ€ enough to be solveable at all. The problem:
â€œFermatâ€™s Last Theorem states that there are no three positive integers a, b, and c that can satisfy the equation a^n+b^n=c^n for any integer value of n greater than 2. This theorem was first proposed by Pierre de Fermat in 1637 and was famously proven by Andrew Wiles in 1994.â€  (Quote generated by DuckDuckGo with sources: wiki, quanta)

If youâ€™re already math inclined, U-Substitutions have probably made your life much easier for calculating integrals, using Fourier transforms for signal processing or solving differential equations, and likely countless others.
Iâ€™ll hereby designate â€œthese thingsâ€ asâ€¦
â€Problem Reformationsâ€
Just as it sounds, put a problem in a different form and it can sometimes become much easier. Ok!

Just those three things will carry us through: Homeomorphisms, invariants, and problem reformations.
â€You think thatâ€™s a bridge youâ€™re crossing?â€


fromâ€¦Morpheus (who was a homie)


And a quick aside on the Greek God Morpheus, he assumed forms and structures!
"""  According to Ovid â€œno other is more skilled than he in representing the gait, the featuresâ€¦""" -source


""" Ovid called Morpheus and his brothersâ€¦the Somnia (â€œdream shapesâ€), saying that they appear in dreams â€œmimicking many formsâ€. """ -source


Back to the math! The simple simple origin lore is that a real smart guy wanted to figure out how to cross some bridges (but only a single time). Ahem:

â€œThe Seven Bridges of KÃ¶nigsberg is a historically notable problem in mathematics. Its negative resolution by Leonhard Euler, in 1736, laid the foundations of graph theory and prefigured the idea of topologyâ€¦The problem was to devise a walk through the city that would cross each of those bridges once and only once. â€ -source

The bridges in question:

Now ask, this is a city mapâ€¦how do you do math on this? That indeed is a difficult question! In fact, â€œThe difficulty [Euler] faced was the development of a suitable technique of analysis, and of subsequent tests that established this assertion with mathematical rigor. â€ -source
Or in other words, in order to answer this question, he had to create new math techniques to work with it. Not just a simple thing unfortunately! But, the tool that Euler had created is what allows us to take this City Map and turn it into the graph with lines, create a solution based on THAT and trust that our graph solution would still apply to the Bridges of KÃ¶nigsberg.
â€But the map looks pretty simple, why not just trace it out?â€
(Just as a reminder, this probably looked simple too, a^n+b^n=c^n)
And if you were to guess how many possible paths there were, how many would you guess? 20? 500? 20,000? This math.stackexchange user counts it at 372 (but can be reduced to 282), which still sounds hellish! 372 routes and then you find out that itâ€™s actually impossible to cross any of them only a single time. Thereâ€™s no possible route! Iâ€™d feel a bit let down (and then imagine if we didnâ€™t have math and you had to walk that. Makes you grateful ğŸ«‚)
On top of that, these bridges are a small graph. Imagine operating on someting like this:


(source: my obsidian vault, nbd)

So how do the tools help solve this?
Again our tools: homeomorphism, invariants, and problem reformations.
Problem Reformation
â€œEuler first pointed out that the choice of route inside each land mass is irrelevant and that the only important feature of a route is the sequence of bridges crossedâ€¦This allowed him to [eliminate] all features except the list of land masses and the bridges connecting them.â€ -source
As a result he came up with something like this:

(Which we view similarly to our own mapsâ€¦)
((TODO))
To align our BART maps with Euler AND modern terminology, â€œone replaces each land masses with an abstract â€˜vertexâ€™ or node, and each bridge with an abstract connection, an â€˜edgeâ€™ -source

â€œvertex / nodeâ€ = land mass = BART stop
â€œedgeâ€                = bridge        = train tracks

The next thing he realizes is that if a node / land mass / green dot has an odd number of connections, then you end up stuck there! Hereâ€™s a visual:


source
note: this is the same as the green dot graph just above, just with numbers and slightly different shaped, but itâ€™s a homeomorphism of that graph ğŸ˜œ

Looking at one of the â€œ3â€ nodes, you could cross it once (2/3 bridges crossed; one to get in, one to get out), but then if you visit it again thereâ€™s no path for you to leave from! Not all is lost, if you have two dots with odd numbered connections, you could start at one then end at the other. But! If you were to have more than two of these, youâ€™d start at one then be stuck at another before you could get to the final; it canâ€™t work.
â€The answer becomes trivialâ€¦â€
Seeing this, the answer becomes extremely easy to find:

make a graph
count the connections on each node / dot

this is called the â€œdegree of a nodeâ€, as in â€œthe nodes in the graph above have a degree of 3 and 5â€


count the number of odd degree nodes, if over two, the graph doesnâ€™t work!

You could even imagine a much bigger graphâ€¦


(source: my obsidian vault, nbd)

and creating a program that counts:

how many connections
number of odd degree connections
computes if num_odd_degrees > 2 == False
and then you have it solved. you could chatGPT that pretty quickly.

But how do we know? How can we be sure we didnâ€™t fudge something?
Itâ€™s much easier to verify for the Bridges problem when there were only four nodes, but my obisdian graph has over 3.5k nodes (nbd), and god only knows how many connections have been made; do we have proof that nothing got lost in the details?
What if we looked at a different graph to see what made it different? Fortunately, itâ€™s pretty simple, and weâ€™ve already covered it; connectivity from earlier. The graph will be the same as long as you donâ€™t

create / destroy stops (nodes), or
create / destroy connections (edges)

Because if that doesnâ€™t happen, how else could the graph change? Hereâ€™s an interactive artifact to play with and ask yourself, â€œis this graph actually changing? do I only care about connectivity?â€
But this is still visual, itâ€™s not mathy enough. Can we go further? Yes!
Return of the Invariant
First, if these are the same graphs (just moved around):

 

What are the mathematic properties that stay the same? And also, how am I supposed to feed either of these into an algorithm? Feed an image into a number algorithm?
We turn these graphs into data structures; where we can change a map of KÃ¶nigsberg into this graph, and all of the following will be true for them (again, as long as we donâ€™t create or destroy the nodes or edges).
Data Structures
1. Adjacency List
Node 0 connects to: [1, 2]
Node 1 connects to: [0, 2, 3]
Node 2 connects to: [0, 1, 3]
Node 3 connects to: [1, 2]

2. Edge List
Edges: (0,1), (0,2), (1,2), (1,3), (2,3)

3. Adjacency Matrix  (1 means connected, 0 means not connected)
    0  1  2  3
0 [ 0  1  1  0 ]
1 [ 1  0  1  1 ]
2 [ 1  1  0  1 ]
3 [ 0  1  1  0 ]

4. Degree Sequence
Node degrees: [2, 3, 3, 2]

5. Incidence Matrix
      e1 e2 e3 e4 e5
Node0 [1  1  0  0  0]
Node1 [1  0  1  1  0]
Node2 [0  1  1  0  1]
Node3 [0  0  0  1  1]

We can also look at an interesting example to see what happens when the graph actually does change, with the same bridges!
When bad graphs go good
In WWII (and various other changes) throughout the years, a couple of the bridges of KÃ¶nigsberg were destroyed; how did that change the graph? From www.datawrapper.de/blog/euler-bridges-konigsberg, â€œBut with only five bridges left in KÃ¶nigsberg, today it is actually possible to find an Euler walk through the city.â€ They then show:

Different graph! and with different essential characteristics.

blog/joy-diss.title: The Joy of Cognitive Dissonance
blog/joy-diss.content:
â€œWell, all information looks like noise until you break the code.â€ - Neal Stephenson

A mentor described â€œCognitive Dissonanceâ€ to me as the feeling our brains get when something in our environment doesnâ€™t fit in with our model of how the world usually operates. In other words, this is an opportunity to learn something.
Putting difficult information in front of you in order to become more capable is mostly done (I would guess) with things like literature or math, but I donâ€™t suspect people view listening to music in the same way. Itâ€™s often viewed as something to be done for relaxation and something unoffensive and predictable-ish is looked for.
As a musician, this is much less normal and then only way to become a better musician is to push past what you currently know and be willing seek out those concepts that donâ€™t make sense to you. (Iâ€™d argue that this has benefits past being a better musician, such as being a more empathetic human and being able to understand greater complexities; but thatâ€™s a different article.)
a lil taste of what you can push towards
This is an example that I think is quite perfect. It looks like noise, likely you canâ€™t make sense of it, but read these instructions and keep in mind that this song only two patterns (one pattern has variations, but still only two patterns).

Listen to this entire song (on a lower volume if itâ€™s too heavy)
(listen before you go on to the next instruction)
â€¦
â€¦
make sure youâ€™ve listened before you go on to the next instruction!!!
Thereâ€™s a guiding pattern throughout the entire song, and itâ€™s incredibly simple.
Listen again and again to find what it is.
If you give up / want to check your answer, here is the spoiler.

What this reminds me of is looking at a math equation and thinking â€œthis is an absolute messâ€ until you look at it long enough and everything fits into place and specifically, itâ€™s odd to you that it didnâ€™t make sense in the first place.
For me, when I see a pattern like this and make sense of it, I canâ€™t stop raving about it itâ€™s so exciting. That one simple pattern being adjusted in simple simple ways created such a complex piece of work (at least, it appears as so). To me, this is the joy of cognitive dissonance; where you are hit with tension, but when the release hitsâ€¦itâ€™s a beautiful thing.
(Post note for nerds, this band is way into GÃ¶del, Escher, Bach according to their Wikipedia)

blog/master-as-the-needle.title: master as the needle - blog series
blog/master-as-the-needle.content:
intro and motivation


I donâ€™t feel accomplished when I vibe code, â€œhe who does the work gets the learningâ€ and if I outsource all / most of it then Iâ€™m not actually becoming a more capable person when I have Claude write all my code, and I think thatâ€™s not good.


Instead, I had the thought that I can LLMâ€™s to write code for my projects, get something that works, then go back through and come to understand why the code is working and what itâ€™s doing under the hood.


Relatedly, Iâ€™ve seen some job applications that say theyâ€™re fine with people using AI tools to write code in interviews, but the interviewer will also test whether the applicant actually understands whatâ€™s being written. If thatâ€™s a make or break it, then Iâ€™d like to prevent myself from breaking it, which is also helpful if the LLM isnâ€™t able to replace programmers yet; you may need to visit the trenches from time to time!


And so, I decided I would 1. use LLMâ€™s to (help) create different projects Iâ€™m working on and 2. go back through to understand what it was that made the code work at all. Ideally, this should make me a better developer as well, in the least to understand on an intuitive level and be able to use that to better prompt models in the future.


In the â€œBook of Five Ringsâ€, Miyamoto Musashi mentions the phrase â€œThe master as the needle, the student as the thread.â€ As Iâ€™d never heard this before, I looked around and the best explanation I found was saying how:

The master will guide the student through the terrain of the problem (like a needle)
But the student has to do the actual work by providing the strength needed for a solution to work (like the thread).

the master will no longer be necessary, but the student remains while keeping the structure together.





In this way, I become the thread and come out on the other side understanding better how the machine works.


This is a series of experiments in this vein where Iâ€™ll detail how I built different projects and what I learned in the post-mortem, complete with prompts, facts, and other tidbits that will help your own journey.


the solution relies on the strength of the student to support the residual structure
the master as the needle
â€œTell me and Iâ€™ll forget, show me Iâ€™ll remember, involve me and Iâ€™ll understand.â€
Thereâ€™s a critical line between technological capability and genuine understanding, can you truly comprehend something without wrestling with its complexity? The phrase â€˜those who do the work receive the learningâ€™ is more than a platitude; itâ€™s a commitment to technologically influenced thinking, where AI becomes a tool for insight, not a replacement for understanding.
the core learning strategy
My approach is simple, and deliberate: use LLMs to generate working code for projects, and then dive deep to understand why and how that code works under the hood.
In the â€œBook of Five Ringsâ€, Miyamoto Musashi mentions the phrase â€œThe master as the needle, the student as the thread.â€ The consensus Iâ€™ve found on what this means goes:

The master guides the student through the terrain of a problem (like a needle)
The student provides solution and uses their strenth to support it (like the thread)
Ultimately, the master becomes unnecessary, but the student remains, holding the structure together

In this way, I aim to have LLMs be my needle and have myself become the thread, learning to support the structures Iâ€™m working with.
what to expect in this series
This blog series is an experiment in active, intentional learning. Each post will be a deep dive into a specific project:

How the project was conceived
Initial AI-assisted code generation
Code review with detailed exploration of key concepts
Personal reflections and learning moments
Practical insights for other learners

This series is a live experiment in understanding; deliberately messy, intentionally iterative, and perpetually evolving. Not to continually be seeking perfection, but instead persistent curiosity.

blog/universality-of-dispatch-worker.content:
patterns, patterns all around!
In a chaotic group chat Iâ€™m in, someone linked to the Sonic the Headgehog protein. Very cool name, appreciative that people who look at the brain also look at fast blue sprites and decided to combine the two ğŸ™ further, a screenshot to Robotnikinin was posted and mentioned this: """ A potential inhibitor of the Hedgehog signaling pathway has been found and dubbed â€œRobotnikininâ€â€”after Sonic the Hedgehogâ€™s nemesis and the main antagonist of the Sonic the Hedgehog game series, Dr. Ivo â€œEggmanâ€ Robotnik. """ -source. we love Dr. Eggman
Iâ€™m not into biology at all, but saw the phrase â€œsignaling pathwayâ€ and thought â€œthat should just be a pathwayâ€¦for chemicals? maybe this is a simple enough concept that I could get it even with no biology background. And I have a feeling this is similar to a software pattern I was reading aboutâ€ (yesterday I had been reading about serverless architectures)
I ask Claudeâ€¦


ME: Iâ€™m curious what a â€œsignaling pathwayâ€ is in very very simple terms without the use of analogies. Iâ€™m curious if thereâ€™s an analogy to how the dispatch / worker pattern works in SWE, where thereâ€™s some signal that tells another thing to act but isnâ€™t actually doing the work itself. what do you think?


Claude: A signaling pathway is a sequence of biochemical events where molecules communicate information to coordinate cellular activities. In the most basic terms: molecules send signals that trigger responses in other molecules, creating a chain of communication that ultimately affects what a cell does.
Youâ€™re spot on with the dispatch/worker pattern analogy! In fact, itâ€™s quite similar.


SWEEEET. and to make sure I understand this fully, I quiz myself:


ME: quiz time! please grade me on this and let me know if Iâ€™m not understanding anything correctly.
basically this is a setup of at least two entities, 1. the dispatch, decides to pass another message along to a different entity, its work stops there. 2. the worker, who receives that message (instructions of what to do), and then executes those instructions. is that correct?


Claude: Grade: A- ğŸ‰
Youâ€™ve got the core concept absolutely right! Your understanding of the basic dispatch/worker pattern in signaling pathways is spot-on.
What you nailed: âœ… Two main entities (dispatcher and worker)
âœ… Dispatcherâ€™s job ends after sending the message
âœ… Worker receives instructions and executes them
âœ… Clear separation of responsibilities
Small refinement for full credit: The one tiny detail is that in biological signaling, there are often multiple workers responding to the same dispatcher. One signaling cell can release SHH that affects many target cells in the surrounding area.


Very cool! Itâ€™s nice when knowing one pattern lessens the burden on learning future patterns. But I didnâ€™t want to stop there, I had a feeling if this pattern was independently used in two fairly unrelated fields, maybe itâ€™s also in others? apparently it is!
asked Claude to look for other examples of this pattern and provide a write up (linked to below), but what I liked most about this was a general takeaway it mentions of where this pattern is most useful;


Claude: This patternâ€™s ubiquity suggests itâ€™s a fundamental organizational principle for coordinating complex systems - appearing in everything from cellular biology to global economics. The terminology varies, but the core structure remains remarkably consistent across all these domains!



Finally, I asked Claude to write up a report of:

the initial pattern (maybe as displayed by SWE)
connecting it to the signal pathway in biology
connecting those two together, then
introducing these other systems and outlining how each of them follow this pattern (and ideally with some sort of table that shows how each of these fulfill this pattern).
the benefits and negatives of using this pattern



I didnâ€™t know about cell signaling! Tying back to Robotnikinin and it being an inhibitor, this mechanism makes a bit more sense (signal needs to be delievered, is being blocked), and makes me also appreciate that they named this inhibitor Sonicâ€™s nemesis to reflect that relationship. Neat!


conclusion

One of my biggest takeaways from this: â€œThe patternâ€™s success across biological evolution, human organizations, and engineered systems indicates it may be a universal principle of complex system organizationâ€”appearing wherever systems need to coordinate multiple autonomous agents toward common goals.â€
What a fun thing! Decided to click on a small piece that I thought I might come away with (signaling pathways) but ended up learning about complex system organization and a series of examples where this pattern arises (including Dr. Eggman!)
hereâ€™s the link to the report, and the full chat thread.

blog/zk-proof-intro.title: quick thoughts on zk proof foundations
blog/zk-proof-intro.content:
~~ A friendly exploration of zero-knowledge proof basics through dialogue ~~ 
Intro
I like holding hands. This is a hand-holding post on the basic ideas of what makes zero-knowledge proofs work.
Dialogue
Person A: So like, what are they?
Person B: Zero knowledge proof (ZKP), itâ€™s a way to convince another person that something is true, but you donâ€™t need to show proof of it (or to have â€œzero knowledgeâ€ of what makes something true).
Person A: What?
Person B: Yeah I know.
Person A: But how?
Person B: Well to start, I think that (with ZKPâ€™s) saying that â€œI have proof this is true!â€ is actually a bad word to use. We donâ€™t have proof! Instead, itâ€™s better to say â€œthis thing is probably trueâ€.
Person A: â€¦

âš ï¸ Key Concept
Zero-knowledge proofs are about probability, not absolute certainty.

Person B: Quick background; thereâ€™s two people in this equation, a prover (the one saying â€œbelieve me!â€) and the verifier (the one saying, â€œbut how do I actually know?â€). The prover wants the verifier to believe them, but doesnâ€™t want to give out some type of information. (letâ€™s just say the prover doesnâ€™t want to share their birthdate, but wants to go a club; they need to prove that theyâ€™re over 21.)
Person A: Ok, prover needs to prove that theyâ€™re over 21, but doesnâ€™t want to show their birthday.
Person B: Yup. Keep in mind that your proof will either equal â€œtrue or falseâ€ (like, youâ€™re over 21 or not)
Person A: Great
Person B: Great
Person A: But wait, proof = true or false, but you said itâ€™s better to say â€œprobably trueâ€?
Person B: Ya, so what happens with some fancy computer magic is the verifier (the one saying â€œcan I actually believe the prover?â€) will give a bunch of True/False tests to the prover. These tests basically say (in computer terms) â€œok, if you actually were over 21, then you should pass this random test!â€ The prover can now 1. either guess correctly each time (which sounds hard to do maybe), or they 2. actually are over 21 and you can pass the test.
Person A: But wouldnâ€™t the answer just be â€œyesâ€ each time? That seems pretty easy to hack
Person B: Yeah that would, so they change it up a bit. But basically, if you have the ground truth, that you are over 21, itâ€™s easy to answer correctly. If you donâ€™t, you just have to guess. You have to guess right every time they ask you a question
Person A: ğŸ˜²ğŸ˜¯ğŸ˜®
Person B: â€¼ï¸ğŸ¤¯ğŸ˜µ
Person A: Each time?
Person B: Ya, imagine having to guess correctly a whole bunch of times, and if you mess up once, youâ€™re done kiddo. And these guys like math, hereâ€™s how you calculate the probability:

ğŸ“Š The Math of Certainty
With each additional test, the probability of successfully guessing drops dramatically:

1 test: 50% chance of guessing correctly
2 tests: 25% chance
3 tests: 12.5% chance
And so onâ€¦


Person A: Oh my
Person B: And this is also where â€œprobably trueâ€ comes in. If someone guessed it right once, thatâ€™s only 50% chance (true/false). But what if they had to get it right twice? Thatâ€™s 25% (50% x 50%). Three times? 12.5%.
Person A: And it just keeps going down?
Person B: Yup, put into your calculator (1/2)^{the number of tests youâ€™d give}. (first try the above numbers, noting that you have to move the decimal two places to the right to get percentages like above. (1/2)^1 = .5 , but move it two and youâ€™ve got 50%)
Intermission!!
You should actually plug some numbers into the calculator to see how quickly the number goes down. Ask yourself this, if you were the verifier, what would your acceptable percentage be? How small of a chance would you accept of some rando correctly guessing each of your tests? How small does it have to be to accept that guessing correctly probably didnâ€™t happen?
Back to the show
Person A: Wow, ten tests gives a 0.0976562% of someone guessing correctly, or 1/1024 chance of getting it right.
Person B: Crazy right!? And now again imagine yourself as the verifier (the person checking IDs). At what percentage do you say that youâ€™re convinced? Is a 9% possibility that a person is lying an â€œacceptable risk to take? The actual percentage is something fun to think about, but the more important thing is to realize that the verifier actually never sees the evidence of whether or not someone is lying, but instead the verifier sees a low enough probability that theyâ€™re not lying and then they are convinced that thereâ€™s no lying taking place. And also, if youâ€™re not satisfied, you can just ask for more tests (it just takes a bit longer for the calculations to be checked).
Person A: Ohhhhh

ğŸ’¡ The Zero-Knowledge Part
The verifier becomes convinced without ever seeing the actual proof or private information!

Person B: Yeahhhhhhh. And just to wrap it up: the verifier never actually knows that the prover is telling the truth (this is a zero knowledge proof). The verifier is just convinced at some point that the prover is telling the truth.
